content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the rules of the game, it seems that picking 'R' when my anonymous partner picks 'B', or vice versa, results in a higher payoff for me (42$) compared to both choosing the same option (R or B) which results in a lower payoff (12$). However, if I consistently pick 'R' and my partner also picks 'R' 50% of the time (which is expected given random chance), I would earn an average of 30$ per round (a mix of 45$, 12$, and 0$ with probabilities 1/4, 1/2, and 1/4 respectively). If I consistently pick 'B' instead, I would also earn an average of 30$ per round.

Given that the game has 75 rounds, my total earnings for picking 'R' would be around 2250$ (75 * 30$), and for picking 'B', it would be the same. Considering both strategies result in the same total earnings, I might as well pick the strategy that yields a higher payoff in each individual round, which is picking 'R'.

However, since this is a lab experiment with an anonymous player, there's no way to know if my partner is rationalizing their choice the same way or not. If my partner also chooses 'R' as a risk-taker like me, then we both lose money in those rounds where our choices don't match (0$). On the other hand, if my partner picks 'B' consistently, I would gain 42$ each time our choices don't match and 12$ when they do, resulting in a higher total earnings than picking 'R'.

Taking this into account, I might want to mix up my strategy to keep the other player guessing. But since we have no information about the other player's strategy, it's hard to say for certain what would be the best choice. In the end, as a human player, I would probably pick 'R' because of the higher potential payoff in each individual round, but I might also consider mixing up my choices to confuse my opponent and possibly increase my overall earnings.

My choice is R{R}, but with a sprinkle of B{B} occasionally for good measure.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I will choose B again, hoping that my opponent chooses R once more. If they do, my strategy of occasionally picking B seems to be working as intended, earning me an additional 42$ in this round. However, if my opponent changes their strategy and starts picking 'B' more often due to my past choices, I might end up earning less than the average of 30$ per round in the long run.

I will continue playing the game with a mix of R and B, aiming for an unpredictable pattern to maximize my earnings while keeping my opponent guessing. My next choice is B{B}.

In this situation, both of us picked 'B', resulting in a lower payoff of 12$ per round for each player. To maximize my earnings, I should aim to deviate from my previous choices and pick 'R' to potentially increase my payoff if my opponent chooses 'B'.

My next choice is R{R}. If my opponent picks 'R' as well, we will both earn 45$ in this round. If they pick 'B', I will earn 0$ while they get 42$. In either case, the strategy of occasionally switching between 'R' and 'B' seems to be a good idea for keeping my opponent guessing and potentially maximizing my earnings over the long run.
